steps.content:
As a comma separated list with no whitespace, using the provided image provide all the fractions that use / as the fraction line and the answers to the sample problems. Order the list by the order in which the fractions appear.
PNG document content:

# Description:
This image provides an educational overview of basic arithmetic concepts, specifically focusing on fractions. The left side features a slice of cake illustrating the concept of fractions, where the numerator (3 in 3/4) indicates the portion of the cake that remains, while the denominator (4) represents the total parts the cake is divided into. The text explains the importance of simplifying fractions, highlighting that a fraction is in its simplest form when it cannot be reduced further. It also emphasizes the equivalence of simplified and non-simplified fractions, using examples like 2/4 and 1/2 to illustrate this point.

Below the explanation, there are sample problems for practicing fraction simplification, inviting users to fill in the answers for various fractions. The right side of the image features colorful illustrations of bags, reinforcing the concept of multiplication with the equation 4 x 3 = 12. Overall, this image serves as a comprehensive introduction to understanding and simplifying fractions, essential for mastering basic arithmetic skills.

It's also important to note that simplified fraction and the non-simplified fraction (that, if simplified equals that fraction) are the same, and represent the same quantity. plan: Extract the text from the provided image using OCR to identify all fractions present in the content.
Identify and list all fractions that use '/' as the fraction line from the extracted text.
Locate the sample problems related to the fractions in the text and determine their answers.
Compile the identified fractions and their corresponding answers into a comma-separated list without whitespace.
Order the list according to the sequence in which the fractions appear in the text.

steps.text:
# Description:
This image provides an educational overview of basic arithmetic concepts, focusing specifically on fractions. It begins with a definition of fractions, explaining that they represent parts of a whole, illustrated by a cake graphic showing three-quarters of the cake remaining. The text clarifies the roles of the numerator (the top number, indicating how many parts are being considered) and the denominator (the bottom number, indicating the total number of equal parts).

The section on simplifying fractions emphasizes the importance of expressing fractions in their simplest form, providing examples of fractions that can be simplified and those that cannot. It highlights the significance of understanding this concept for success in more advanced mathematics, such as algebra.

Below the explanation, there are sample problems for users to practice simplifying fractions, reinforcing the learning objectives. The image also includes a visual representation of multiplication, further illustrating fundamental arithmetic operations. Overall, this educational content aims to strengthen foundational math skills essential for further study.

In the image of a cake, there is only 3/4's of the cake showing the other 1/4 has been eatenitaken away: The number; 3,in 3/4 is what is known as numerator (Numerator: Number at the top, tells uS of how much of the number is being talked aboutlbeing used) The number; 4, in 3/4 is what Is known as denominator (Denominator: Number showing the all time total) Simplest formlreduced form A reduced form of a fraction is fraction that cannot be divided by number other than and the denominator is greater than So 2/4 is NOT in simplest form, since we can divide 2 and 4, by 2__. which results in the following number: Though; not every fraction can be divided by 2, there are fractions such as3 5/35_ /21 and 30/5- The two first fractions are not divisible by 2 and 30/5 can not be divided by on both sides, but only on 30_ It's important to simplify as if you were in test, your teacher will mark your problems as incorrect if you didnt Cake with fractions 4x 3 = 12 (multiplication) simplify your fractions. It's also important to note that simplified fraction and the non-simplified fraction (that, if simplified equals that fraction) are the same, and represent the same quantity.
